For the first three months I loaded up some apps from the Play store, copied over some videos and music and basically used it as my primary computer, including contacts and calendar. I stored lots of photos and other documents and carried it around all the time.Then, a few days ago, after shutting it off it would not boot. It would constantly stay on the "X" logo and never go past that. I tried resetting it many times, searched the forums for answers and then called Google. After some diagnostics over the phone they told me that there was nothing they could do and to call ASUS. I then called ASUS, and after an hour of pressing this button and that they told me we needed to do a factory reset and wipe the device. I shuddered and agreed and then went ahead. After wiping the device completely clean of everything I had on it, restoring it to factory settings, we tried to reboot it and the same thing occurred. It would get to the "X" and go no further.The telephone support then told me I needed to package up the device and send it in to be repaired which will take roughly three weeks, IF they have the parts. So after spending over an hour packaging the device, taking it to the post office and having it shipped out, here I sit without a tablet.At this point, only three months after purchasing the device, I have now lost all of my data, spent  over $300 + shipping costs (which I had to pay) and have nothing to show for it. Also, having spent 2.5 hours on the phone and another hour packaging and shipping the device, not to mention the time I spent trying to boot it back up myself. The best case scenario now is that they can somehow fix the device and send it back, basically a refurb, and then hope that it will work correctly and is worth going back and reinstalling all of my apps and data from the beginning.Before this experience I always viewed Google as a quality company and I highly recommended the Nexus to my friends and family. In light of this experience I am not impressed. I will consider this my last purchase of any kind with the name Google or Asus, and the first of many complaints to my friends and family of the poor quality of Google products, and its services.

Reviews.Title: DOA Seems Common Problem
Reviews.Author: Robin
Reviews.Content: Ordered the 32GB Nexus 7 for a Christmas present for the wife. Would not take a charge and would only boot twice while the charger was connected. Seems to be a common problem with the Nexus 7. Reading other reviews, identical issue. Returned to vendor but they seem not even trying to replace and just issued a refund. Perhaps they know something. A previous query to ASUS on this problem got nothing but deafening silence. Contacting Google got a sympathetic autoresponder. Getting my money back and being away from the Nexus 7 is probably a good thing.

Reviews.Title: Amazing out of the box, then  :(
Reviews.Author: r0b
Reviews.Content: I followed the quick start instructions, charged up the device, read the manual, then powered up the device. It was working great, I loaded it up with apps, brought it in my truck, and plugged it in to my usb charger, no problems there. I plugged it in at home, it recognized that it was charging. the next day, I updated the o.s. as prompted, and then the device only would charge while turned off, and was no longer recognized by my p.c.. I restored to factory settings without the problem being resolved, and now must use dropbox to load local media. It's a great device, just buy it from somewhere local so that exchanges are easy.

Reviews.Title: Awesome tablet, with a couple slight annoyances
Reviews.Author: Brian C. Driver
Reviews.Content: For background - I have had a budget Android tablet and several Android phones for personal use, and I have an iPad and an iPhone for work, and my wife has a Nook Color, so I am well-versed in mobile technology and capability.I've had this tablet for around a month, and overall, I quite like it.  I got it primarily for web-browsing, ebooks (via the Nook app), and games, with some light productivity, mostly around the house.  I had expected to continue to use my mobile to listen to music at home, and to check Facebook and email, since it's "pocketable" and I have it on my most of the time.  As it turns out, the Nexus, while not something I'd take out with me running errands, fits nicely in a front pants pocket, and I find myself using it almost exclusively as my mobile device while I'm at home, for everything but phone calls.Here are the details:Pros:*The screen is amazing - very crisp, with deep blacks, great viewing angles, and accurate color representation.  Coming from a Super AMOLED screen on my phone, I was a bit worried, since this is a basic ISP panel, but it's awesome.  Touch response is quick and accurate as well.*Super-quick quad-core CPU - this had taken almost everything I've thrown at it with little slowdown.  Oddly, Facebook sometimes gives it pause, but most people I know have some problems with the Facebook mobile app.  Installs apps super-quick after downloading, and loads them up quickly as well.*Smooth, fast graphics - I can't believe how good the graphics are getting on tablets these days.  No complaints - 3d games play smoothly, with very little lag or stuttering.*Super-quick Wifi - I have a 25Mbps Fios connection, and this tablet maxes it out, even over wifi-G.  Downloaded a 1.3 GB game in a few minutes.*Jelly Bean 4.2 interface - Smooth animations, and I love the widgets available.*Swype-like keyboard in 4.2 (you might have to upgrade out of the box) - I got hooked on Swype on my Samsung GS II phone, but was worried about how it would work on a tablet with the larger screen.  While the keyboard isn't actually Swype, but rather an Android-stock knock-off, it works very well. Only complaint is that the function to add words to the dictionary after manually spelling them out is not always available.*Media - video playback is superb, due to the great screen, and the sound is decent-ish without headphones.  Plug headphones in, and the sound is great - not distorted, with decent dynamic range.  Netflix works great, as does Youtube, Vimeo, and other streaming apps.*Form factor/feel - despite minor issues with build quality I touch on below, this is pleasant to hold.  Enough heft you know it's not a cheaply made device, but not too heavy, with a nicely textured rubber back.  The closest thing I can compare it to is the Nook Color - the rubberized back makes both devices easy to hold, although this has a glass bezel, so it gets thumbprints easily.  No worries - the glass cleans nicely with a cloth, or in a pinch, the tail of a t-shirt.*Battery life - lasts from morning to night, while checking email, web, Facebook, etc., watching Youtube videos, and playing lots of games (usually Angry Birds or Minecraft).  Easily lasts 12 hours of light-to-medium intermittent use throughout the day.*Standard Micro-USB port - THANK YOU!  So many tablets these days use proprietary charging/data ports, so this was very refreshing, and since I have several high-current USB chargers, I'm not lacking for places to plug this thing in, when the battery finally does die.Cons*Build quality - as I mentioned above, there are a couple minor issues.  For one, there's a plastic trim ring running around the device, that has a bit of flex in it.  And due to this, it appears the glass on the left side (viewing it in portrait mode) is pushed up a bit.  This is only an illusion - the plastic trim ring has warped a bit, so that the edge of the glass is exposed by a hair's breadth, where on the other sides of the device, the plastic trim is raised above the glass ever-so-slightly.  If I'd spent $500 on this, I might have returned it, but it's acceptable given the price.  Although I do hope Google/ASUS do change this bit of the design on future revisions, as I've read about it in other reviews.  This is what I docked the star off for.*No SD card - worth noting, but since I knew this going in, I didn't dock a star.  I know Google/ASUS wanted to charge a premium for extra storage, but come on - microSD ports wouldn't have added a lot of cost, and wouldn't have required much space.  This was a very Apple thing to do.  That said, 32GB is a lot of storage, and with so many cloud services supported, I mainly only need the local storage for games and to sync Google data.Some apps I'd recommend:Spotify - the best streaming music service I've tried, the app works great on this tabletGrand Theft Auto Vice City - if you liked the original, it will be a blast form the pastMinecraft PE - Minecraft, on a tabletAngry Birds Star Wars - best Angry Birds game so far, IMOGoogle Drive - If it's not already installed (can't remember) get it - this is a great little content creation tabletNook for Android - great reading app, and it works with ePub format, unlike the *other* ebook vendor's reading app (cough, cough)Marvel Comic reader - I'm not a huge comic fan, but after reading a couple free issues, this is the way comics should be readUnified Remote - great remote app to control your PC, with mouse and keyboard capability, it's an awesome app for anyone with a home theater PC who doesn't want to drag out a full-size keyboard.  Get the free version for basic mouse/keyboard/media capability, get the full version for several dozen apps, including every flavor of media player/center, file broswers, power, etc.  My favorite Android app hands down.Advanced Task Killer - lets you easily and quickly shut down background apps, either from a menu, or with a one-touch widgetES File Explorer - easily navigate local storage, and also browse UPnP networked storage.  I use this to pull down movies off my server.

Reviews.Title: Best Bang for your Buck
Reviews.Author: Dragember
Reviews.Content: I'll be honest, I never saw myself owning a tablet, but honestly I felt this one was a bit too good to pass up.Pros:- Cheap! If your not buying off of Amazon, you can find this tablet at $230.00. It's one of the cheapest on the market.- 7 inch display- Gripable back- High resolution screen- Very fast- Runs Jellybean 4.2 (comes with 4.1)- Updates now allow for keyboard swiping- Compact, able to hold in one hand- Good button Locations (on/off and volume are located at the side)- No crashes, can handle multiple apps running at once- Little to no heating, even when extremely active- Great Battery life- None slip air pockets on back- Google now, Sbeam, and other awesome features- HTML Browser- Has 32GB of Flash Memory- Has 720p video (comes with a quality cap that you can break with an app to get the full potential.)- Has 1 GB of RAM- Has GPS- Has Blutooth- Weight is .7 lbs and is well distributed- Scratch Proof Corning® Fit GlassCons:- Auto correct is sometimes dumb.- No USB port- No SIM Slot- Poor speakers- No back facing camera- front facing camera has poor quality (1.2 MP). The Video is 720P, haven't tested it yet.- No Flash Support- No Radio (can stream online radio)- No GPRS (Cannot connect to 4G, 3G networks, though there is a Nexus that can)- No EDGENow something I love about this tablet is the screen resolution. 1280x800, it has better image quality than the iPad Mini. The Nexus 7 has 216 ppi compared to the iPad Mini's 163 ppi, overall the Nexus 7 has a higher density pixel display. My uncle, who works for Microsoft is envious of it's quality display when compared to his iPad Mini (he hates Microsoft products). The display has a contrast ratio of 908:1, which is very excellent. It's really too bad that there aren't amazing speakers to go with this amazing display, and that's the devices's greatest failure in my opinion.The speakers are soft spoken, and when raised too high emit some weak strained audio. They work, they get the job done, but when it comes to watching some Netflix in bed, I get out the headphones. Otherwise they're okay for the on the spot you tubing and what not, they just could be better is all. Here are the stats on decibels:Loudspeaker Voice 68dB / Noise 65dB / Ring 75dBAudio quality Noise -69.8dB / Crosstalk -72.1dBThe keyboard is pretty intelligent and smooth. There have been updates since it's release and one of them included the swipe keyboard. It works really well. My only complaint is that occasionally it auto corrects something oddly, but that's not something an update could easily solve.Now for me the camera wasn't a very big deal, it's primary purpose I assume would be for skyping. If I'm planning on a skype session, I would probably bring the laptop out. So I don't think I'm ever going to really need the camera. The camera genuinely sucks though, it's pixally and could have been a lot better. Still, I suppose when Google made it, they weren't really intending the user to take high quality photos with their tablet. I'll give them leniency here, since it's a fairly useless feature on a tablet anyways.The Nexus 7 runs on 1GB of ram, and has a Tegra 3 Quad-core processor. Basically it runs very fast. It has yet to freeze up on me, not counting when a crappy app crashes. It can run multiple apps with breeze and smoothly transition through them. Apps load very quickly, as do webpages. Boot up is a matter of a second or so. I love how the unit doesn't overheat, ever.There are two very large copper heat sinks that surround the tablet that give it this ability. I've used this tablet throughout the entire day with multiple apps open, streaming videos, playing games, and it only gives off a mild warmth.The system software itself is amazing. Jellybean works splendidly and is indeed very buttery. Transitions through apps are very graceful and pleasing to the eye. I personally like the color layout the system has (black and a particular blue text). The navigation is very easy to figure out and the tablet is very easy to use. There are a lot of system adjustments you can do, and my personal favorite feature is the message for the lock screen. I have an if found message, being the forgetful person I am I thought this was a nice touch since I don't want to sharpey my name on the device. One of the greatest featues of Android, in my opinion, is the ability to customize your device. There's a nice array of widgets out there, that and some neat live wallpaper. Unlike the iPad Mini, one Nexus' display could look vastly different than the next one, while the iPads only differ in background and App choices. The system is very simple and easy to use, very user friendly.When it comes to browsing the web I've heard a few Flash complaints, since it runs HTML. There are several ways to get around this, but I thought I would just mention that no, the Nexus does not come supporting Flash. The Nexus 7 runs an HTML5 browser, and I haven't had any difficulty with it.With 32 GB of space, you have some room to upload your favorite songs and movies, store some pictures. For $230.00, this is a great amount of memory. Honesty, its a steal, have a look at other tablets and their storage vs. Price - price range.The battery is long lasting. One charge lasts throughout the day on heavy use. Using it lightly, it can last well over 100 hours. This thing is very efficient battery wise. The only thing that drains the battery is the GPS for obvious reasons. Streaming movies, I'd estimate it would last around 11 hours. I've read somewhere that this has to due with it's quad core, and it's extra core. This extra core only runs while it's in sleep mode. This alone helps vastly improve battery life, that and the quad core makes the Android overall very efficient.Finally the design of the tablet. For some, the rubber-pastically like back may be unattractive, to me it's a plus. It prevents slippage, and while the iPad Mini's backing looks more attractive, on cold morning I'd be afraid of shattering it on the floor. There are small indentions all over the back of the Nexus for the purpose of creating more friction. It's supposed to allow a firm grip, even if your palms are sweaty. The face of the Nexus looks very sleek, it doesn't gather much smudge and is very simple to clean. I think the silvery lining around the edge of the device adds a nice touch as well. The face of the screen is made with Corning® Fit Glass, which is scratch resistant. I have yet to get a case for the device, but from what I can tell, there aren't even light surface scratches.Also just a quick bit about Corning® Fit Glass, I'm guessing it's a Corning® product. Asus is using Corning® Fit Glass in all of its newly announced products. Earlier Asus stated that they would be using Corning®Gorilla®Glass2 in all of their 2012 products, so I'm not what's really going on. I'm assuming it's a Corning® product because the title is capitalized, "Fit Glass", on all of the product descriptions, other people assume it's just scratch resistant glass that Corning® fitted for Asus. Whatever your take on it, the glass has so far proven resilient for me, so they are probably using the same technique for making the product as they have for Gorilla®Glass, or better.Here's Asus' statement on it: "ASUS TruVivid technology with Corning® Fit Glass for improved color clarity and scratch resistance."Overall I love this tablet. It's certainly the best bang for your buck. It looks like quality, it feels like quality, best of all, it is quality. I enjoy the size, and feel the 7 inch screen is just right. I can hold this tablet comfortably in one hand, and could even fit it inside my pocket. It's the best deal out there when concerning price and quality. Comparing it to my Uncle's iPad Mini, I'd say it can do everything his can do, only cheaper. As for the Kindle Fire, it's nothing compared to a tablet running full Android with access to the Google app store. I've looked through the Amazon App store, there's such limitation on which apps can be used, it puts a limitation on the device itself. Kindle Fire is much too Amazon based for me, and I like the more open ecosystem that Google's Nexus 7 has to offer.*I haven't tried this out for myself, and quite honestly am not certain how to go about it, but the Nexus can run game streaming... Use controllers, ect? It seems very interesting and I'll add an update, as that's potentially an awesome feature.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Device, Too many complaints,
Reviews.Author: Ben Small
Reviews.Content: If you look online you'll see that there are hundreds of posts on forums about Nexus 7 not charging, etc. After a Year of use, my Nexus 7 died after having it's battery run down and shut off. Ever since then I haven't been able to charge it, even after trying every single solution I could find online, from disconnecting and reconnecting the battery's plugin to trying button combos. This week I decided to get a replacement battery, and after installing it the tablet would boot up like normal but still wouldn't charge. While installing the new battery I noticed that inside the tablet there is enough room for the battery to bump around and get loose, pulling on the plugin for it and making it destroy itself. I'm not the only person with this problem and I think you should rethink your choice because of how often this problem occurs.

Reviews.Title: Dont buy a Nexus7 Tablet
Reviews.Author: TexasLady
Reviews.Content: I have sent my Nexus 7 tablet back 3 times and they have NOT fixed it yet.  The touch screen doesn't work but about 5 seconds then I have to turn it off then back on.  It worked great for awhile then kapot!!! When you call you get Bahamas and then have to send it to Dallas,  I have asked for supervisor before but they always just not available.  Would not even recommend this lousy product to a dog.  The warranty they say comes with it is not worth the time it takes you to hear about it so go look elsewhere for something to spend your money on.

Reviews.Title: Damaged Mini USB port - No charge - DEAD tablet!
Reviews.Author: Diego Nova
Reviews.Content: UPDATE as of April 29th, after 4 months of use:This tablet sucks, the so called "faulty mini USB port" is no longer working... I finally got used to the fact that the tablet should be standing still while charging, but in the past weeks, it's even harder to get the right contact, having to use any kind of things to support the tablet in an angle that the usb port makes contact within the tablet.Now it has come to a point where no matter if I get the right contact, the tablet just doesn't charge or do so very slowly, like 3 or 4% of charge in a 24 hour period... This has render the device totally useless, and as I am not in the USA right now, I cannot do anything about the warranty... I must wait to go back...I won't ever buy anything cheap from ASUS again!--------------------------------------------It's an amazing tablet, good screen resolution, powerful, awesome for gaming.The only thing that has concerned me so far is the faulty mini USB port that comes in the Tablet. After a month of normal use, when the tablet is plugged in to either the computer or wall, the slightest move makes the cable move withing the socket and lose the connection, going on and off if you keep moving it.I thought this was a problem of the mini USB- USB cable that comes with the tablet, but I have tried many cables from Nexus and from Blackberry and I figured out it's only a problem of the faulty socket that is not built well enough to hold strongly the mini USB end of the cable inside it.Well, you just have to let it stay still while charging/transferring data, however if you are an avid gamer who plays lots of HD-battery draining games and have to do so with the tablet plugged in, then it's a big deal... other than that, it's an awesome tablet.PD: I bought 2 tablets, one for me and one for my gf, and both have the same issue

Reviews.Title: Don't do it!
Reviews.Author: karoc
Reviews.Content: Don't be fooled by the hype!Pros:  Makes a great paperweightI got the Nexus 7 made by Asus for Christmas.  Within a few weeks, it locked up.  I ended up having to reset it to factory preset.  It locked up again after less than 2 months of use.  Online suggestions to repair it did not work.  Asus Customer Support was unable to provide repair instructions that worked by phone.OK fine, I can understand that but under their warranty, the return shipping for repair was at my cost! Once "repaired", it was returned to me with a signature required via a shipper who only delivers Mon-Fri between 8-5pm.  Guess what - I'm at work!So, I called Asus and after a lengthy phone call, I think that the issue will be fixed and my nexus will be rerouted to my work.  No, not so.I have now made 3 phone calls to Asus and spent over 3 hours trying to resolve this issue.  I still don't know how/if I will ever see my Nexus again.  Their customer service is horrible.  They apologize about a gazillion times but can't resolve the problem.Of course, I have no idea if it has been really repaired or not.  I really wonder if I will ever see it again.Do not buy the Nexus 7.  I am ashamed I was so dazzled by a product with such a lousy record of problems and horrendous customer service.

Reviews.Title: Amazing!
Reviews.Author: Antoniy Vinnitskiy "PRDesignsTony"
Reviews.Content: I used to be into apple products a lot especially after the release of the first iphone. I loved Apple up until i decided to buy an android phone. I love android, the customization is endless. The Nexus 7 is awesome with the new Jelly Bean 4.2 update. Blows away ios 6 in my opinion. Yes i have had my share of using ios 6 especially with a sister that has an ipad. I love the fact that you can had different use profiles like on a windows pc. My wife and I both have separate profiles and have our own apps, which is great. I purchased this as christmas gift for my wife and she loves it, and so do I. This tablet is perfect for gaming. Shadow gun, grand theft auto, and many other Tegra 3 games look amazing as far as mobile gaming goes. Really good tablet all around, the quality is great especially the rubber like backing which feels really nice and comfortable in your hands. I'm very happy with my purchase

Reviews.Title: I use it more than my laptop
Reviews.Author: Blake Harris
Reviews.Content: I bought mine from Office Depot, they're charging an extra 30$ here. Coincidence? Overcharging for the best competitor to the Kindle Fire? I think not, this thing is easily better than the fire, I love mine.  I find myself hardly using my laptop anymore and the battery easily makes it through the day.  I get 6 and a half hours of screen on time if I'm browsing the web, 8 hours or a little more watching movies.  Almost to the point of replacing a desktop, it's coming eventually.  I've got a bluetooth keyboard and a mouse for the OTG cable I got from here and it's like having a little laptop when I need it to be.

Reviews.Title: Excellent!!!! WOW!!!
Reviews.Author: Madgax
Reviews.Content: About The Google Nexus 7:  Mmmm...The good: The Nexus 7 has a beautifully sharp screen. It's light, durable, and has the fastest processor of any Android tablet. the Nvidia Tegra 3 with excellent graphics. Google play is the best content ecosystem with android in the latest version. It's free Android OS. The sound is good and liitle low, but with headphones is very good.The bad: Only the included charger isn't fast enough to power the battery while playing a game and it's very short; even while idle, it charges painfully slowly.

Reviews.Title: Pure android.
Reviews.Author: Samuel Duarte
Reviews.Content: Excellent tablet is light and easy to carry. Quickly updated to latest android versión (kitkat 4.4.2) as soon as I connected to internet,  no bloatware and 3g working good (had to configure apn manually).

Reviews.Title: A terrible piece of equipment
Reviews.Author: David Gould
Reviews.Content: This tablet has been sent back by me five (5) times in the last year.  It will not hold a charge.  This is the worst piece of electronic equipment that I have purchased in the last 30 years.  Do not buy.

Reviews.Title: Asus is terrible.
Reviews.Author: Joseph S. Harbour
Reviews.Content: I bought 2 nexus 7's and an Asus Transformer Tf700 back in Oct 2012 for my family for Christmas. Guess how many survived after the warranty ran out? If you said I would have 3 useless pieces of junk, you guessed correctly. My horrible 1000.00 mistake.I am now saving up for another tablet. Samsung, Apple or Kindle. Anything but an Asus. Their customer service is also the worst I have ever dealt with in the last 20 years.

Reviews.Title: It was DOA
Reviews.Author: Toni Burgess
Reviews.Content: When the Nexus arrived it was "Dead on Arrival" , I tried to charge it but when I plugged it in the charging icon did not display on the screen, it just flickered a couple of times and then went blue.  I went online to the nexus help website and did what they recommended and it still wouldn't work.  I returned it for a full refund and will purchase a different tablet.

Reviews.Title: Tab Died After one year
Reviews.Author: Rakesh
Reviews.Content: Cheap quality build ,usb port broke after six months then exactly after one year  its started having issues with  charging.Battery was charging very slowly(if you charge at night max it will go 10%) what ever charge it has it will discharge very fast. Using as a brick now will never by any product from google even if its cheap .

Reviews.Title: Sound??
Reviews.Author: Eimi Berger
Reviews.Content: The specs were nice, it ran fast, it looked good, but the sound was terrible! I could barely hear even in a quiet room, had to return it

Reviews.Title: Nexus Won't Turn On
Reviews.Author: alwaysherway
Reviews.Content: i had this product only seven months.  I bought it in July 2013.  Now it won't turn on and it won't take a charge.A total waste of money!

Reviews.Title: poor quality and customer service
Reviews.Author: Janine Henry
Reviews.Content: I received the Google Nexus 7 tablet as a gift a few months ago. Within days the camera stopped working. I sent back the tablet because it was still under warranty. The camera was replaced and sent back almost a full month later. Upon receiving the "repaired" tablet the volume controls did not work and scrolling became a problem. I called the company who said they would replace the table. Another month later I got my "new" tablet. Unfortunately it had the same serial number as the old tablet. This new tablet as well had malfunctioning volume controls and scrolling. After 2 months of hassle and using a poorly functioning tablet I am requesting a full refund. I now realize I just should have spent the extra money on an ipad...

Reviews.Title: Peice of junk. Excellent Paperweight.
Reviews.Author: Kolton
Reviews.Content: I highly anticipated this Tablet but was extremely disapointed in it. Out of the box it is ok but once it was a bout half full of music and only a few other apps (nothing intensive or ran in the back ground) it got extremely slow to where it almost was unusable. The only fix I could find was to free up storage. For some reason the memory was almost always atleast 75% full and again I have very few apps that run in the background of the ones that do are very light weight. Unfortunately after about 4 months the USB port just stopped working completely (very well taken care of by the way) and would then charge only on the dock. Well about 2 weeks ago it stopped registering the dock and now won't charge at all. Due to the performance of a cheap $50 phone and lasting less than a year before it randomly stopped working I decided it isn't nowhere near worth its price. I will never by a nexus 7 again and may even be on edge with ASUS products as I have plenty of failures with them before.

Reviews.Title: problem
Reviews.Author: teach
Reviews.Content: I can't charge it. Read on google that need strong electricity current and apparently I don't or the battery was a dude.in any case it is useless. I guess I should have returmed

Reviews.Title: Only worked for 5 MONTHS! Sent back to Asus for warranty claim.
Reviews.Author: jim
Reviews.Content: Worked great for 5 months then it would no longer turn on. I called Asus and we couldn't get it started. So this product was returned to Asus for a warranty claim. I am NOT happy forking out $300 where the tablet stops working AFTER ONLY 5 MONTHS OF USE!

Reviews.Title: Superfast, light, amazing definition.  Half the price of ipad mini.
Reviews.Author: Chisti
Reviews.Content: I bought this for a class (my first tablet) and opted for the Nexus 7 rather than ipad mini for various reasons.  The fact that it is half the price of its competitor was certainly a factor, but it was the speed that sold me.  (something like 27 times faster than ipad)  Also, even I, average sized woman, can hold it in one hand.  The quality of the picture is outstanding.  Almost clearer than real life.  Very happy I made this choice.

Reviews.Title: Poor asus tablet, even poorer customer service
Reviews.Author: asusstinks
Reviews.Content: My first review ever and it is a negative one. The nexus 7 ,which I purchased for my parents, started having the common "power down" problem that has been so commonly cited for this tablet with the first few months. The tablet would just power off and not power back up for a few days. Since my parents were in India, we had to call the customer service in India on the one phone number that was provided. And that single phone number did not work. When we contacted the customer service here in US, they said they could do nothing. Promised call backs from supervisors never happened. And the entire customer service team(I spoke to atleast 8) were unhelpful and rude to say the least. Now 6 months after my first report, the tablet doesn't power on at all and we are out of warranty and Asus expects me to pay for repair of this piece of junk. I have been owning an ipad for years now without any issues. I just feel sorry that I wasted my money on a product which shouldn't be out there in the market. Please don't waste your money and time on this worthless product and crappy customer service.

Reviews.Title: Broke after 2 months!
Reviews.Author: techjay
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my wife and we had to reset it at least twice a week. Called Asus tech support and we did a few things they suggested and we still had to reset it. I thought it was just a glitch with the Android OS but was wrong. Now it won't turn on and is going in for warranty.

Reviews.Title: Consider it disposable
Reviews.Author: mon petit chou
Reviews.Content: I'd just like to post a warning to customers about the Nexus 7 because of my bad experience with ASUS not honoring its warranty. Although I was really impressed at first with the general interface and device, I had problems early on with it charging until finally it stopped charging at all. After some online research, I found many other consumers have had problems with their Nexus degrading within months. As of now, ASUS has been holding my tablet hostage after I sent it in weeks ago for repairs, and now accusing me of 'customer-induced damage, waiting for customer confirmation' - which is not at ALL the case, and no one has contacted me. This is after showing a status of 'repair in progress' for weeks so it doesn't make sense how the status became customer-induced after they had been working on it. Every time I call, no one can give me a solid answer to the status and they just keep telling me to wait for 'the email.' I highly warn anyone from purchasing this item from Google, mainly because of it's ASUS partnership. Really disappointed as I've always thought of Google as a reliable company, but should have done my research about ASUS. Otherwise I've always used Mac products and am used to reliable and prompt tech support. I bought this full price - so pretty much $300 down the drain, as well as all of the apps and books I had purchased on that tablet.

Reviews.Title: Pretty good for the money
Reviews.Author: Nycylith
Reviews.Content: Well worth the money. Batterly life is fairly good, and it feels pretty solid. The speeds are good, but my only gripe is the screen color. I am comparing the resolution to my Samsung Galaxy S3 and it doesn't compare in quality hence the missing star, but everything else is great as others have stated.

Reviews.Title: Is meeting most of my expectations
Reviews.Author: KE
Reviews.Content: Excellent 7 inch tablet, impressed with the Android OS and app store. Some improvements would be an SD slot and a back facing camera

Reviews.Title: My girlfriend is angry
Reviews.Author: filifapion
Reviews.Content: I spend so much time messing with my tablet that my girlfriend has started snarling every time she sees me with it.  I'm not kidding, she snarls.I literally have to pretend I wasn't using it when she walks into the room.  It's worse than my Dad getting on my case about WoW.I love it.  No one can deny my love for it.Seriously, it's amazing; puts up a great fight against the iPad mini

Reviews.Title: Very portable!
Reviews.Author: Isabel M. Villena
Reviews.Content: I bought this to replace my iTouch. I am not at all disappointed. Everything runs beautifully and I like the OS better than Apple's. I wish they had made the bezels smaller on this tablet. The Nexus fits in any type of jean, not shorts, though. If you need an iTouch replacement, this is for you. Portability rocks. Keep in mind it's not an mp3 player but a media consumption device. If you run or do exercise with your device this is not for you though.

Reviews.Title: Nexus 7
Reviews.Author: tony1putt
Reviews.Content: Nexus 7 is the best,nothing better!  screen picture is amazing.  does it all...Why pay for an IPad when you get more for less

Reviews.Title: Best tablet ever
Reviews.Author: Jeff Bell
Reviews.Content: I got this for my girlfriend and she loves it.  If you have an android phone this tablet will not be difficult to use what so ever.

Reviews.Title: Great Tablet for a Great Price.
Reviews.Author: Austin
Reviews.Content: I got this tablet for Christmas and I love it. The screen is amazingly sharp and clear. Way better than the iPad mini. Quad core processor is the most powerful on the market. NVidia Tegra3 is awesome. Great for all ages and needs. only thing that would be better for business is maybe the blackberry playbook. Maybe.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet for the price. The size is great for reading & portability
Reviews.Author: DCG
Reviews.Content: I own an iPad (3rd generation) which I love, but wanted an additional smaller tablet for things like reading. After a lot of research and comparisons to tablets such as the Kindle Fire HD, I went with a Nexus 7.Pros:-The 7" form factor is really good for reading, which is what I primarily got it for. I can hold it comfortably in 1 hand. The faux-leather backing is also comfortable to hold.-Android Jelly Bean is a big improvement over ice cream sandwich.  I had owned an android phone for a couple years in the past before switching to an iPhone, but it's been a year or 2 since I've used it, and they've made some improvements. Ironically, I feel like they improved it by making it even more like iOS. There are some key differences, as Android has widgets, and has different ways of doing some things. While I guess a couple widgets are useful, for the most part, I don't really see the need for them. I tend to just go into apps instead of viewing widgets. Closing open apps is easy, and faster than iOS.-The Google apps that come pre-installed are well designed. I already use many Google services, so setup was easy. Google Now is also well done.-The screen. While the screen is not on par with Apple's retina screen, it is still very nice, and better than most/all of the other non-retina screen tablets currently out there that I've seen.-Google Play. Being able to stream music from Google play is nice to have.-Price. This thing is a realy good tablet for the price.-It's a Nexus/Google tablet, so you'll receive some future OS updates. I don't trust any non-nexus Android devices, as most hardware manufactures just abandon releasing updates for most of their products.Cons:-Lack of apps. I knew this was going to be an issue ahead of time, but it's a bit more an an issue than I expected. First the amount of quality apps available for Android is really not close to the apps available for iOS. A lot of the news apps, guitar/music apps, and toddler apps my daughter uses etc are just not available for Android. Some popular apps seem to just be behind iOS. For example, the Facebook app is pretty much the app that was on iOS about a year ago. The biggest problem is that very few Android apps seem to be optimized for tablets yet. They're mainly phone-apps blown up to fit a larger screen. Being that I mainly got this for reading (and chose it over devices like the Kindle Fire because I do want the additional functionality), I'm not overly concerned with this, but this could be an issue for other people.-Swiping is not as smooth as I'm used to on the iPad. Swiping from side-to-side simply isn't very responsive. I'm not sure whether this is a function of the device, Android, or both. Vertical scrolling seems to lag a bit in some apps, but nothing too bad.-Android Jelly bean is very good, but does not have the same attention to detail as iOS. I've noticed a bunch of small things...such as background images that come with Android not even filling the full screen; I've gotten an 'applauncher' error message a couple times already; and there are some other things they just don't work as well as they should in some cases (ie, moving the curser in Chrome).-Web Browsing. Web browsing can be a bit cumbersome due to the 7" size. Unlike on a phone which loads mobile versions of many sites, and large screen tablets which load fill sites, this loads full desktop sites, but the screen size can make sites it a little tough to navigation without zooming in and out.-The Google Play store. While Google has made some good improvements with Google Play, the Apple App Store is simply much easier to use and find apps.Overall, its a great tablet for the price. I like the 7" size for portability, and for reading for long periods of time. Android is still not as refined as iOS in my opinion, but it's getting there. I don't see this really replacing my iPad in terms of overall use, but it's great for what I wanted it for.

Reviews.Title: Really Good Experience
Reviews.Author: Steven Clark
Reviews.Content: Almost as polished as an iPad. I really like these things for what they are...But my nieces absolutely love them. I got them one each for Xmas and they haven't put them down since.

Reviews.Title: A slick little tablet
Reviews.Author: My thoughts
Reviews.Content: I'm a novice tablet user and I love this tablet. It is incredibly fast, easy to use, easy to hold, and the 1280x800 resolution is sharp and easy on the eyes. It has great voice detection typing, google maps connects to the tablet's GPS and identifies my location, it supports skype, you can touch another device to exchange info, the gorilla glass screen resists scratches, and it connects to my wifi instantly. The 1.2m camera could be better - it does read QR codes but can't scan barcodes. I added the Firefox browser and Firefox Beta enabling me to download Adobe Flash, and then live stream videos.

Reviews.Title: Perfect Tablet
Reviews.Author: Lamartiny S Gomes "Lamartiny Silveira Gomes"
Reviews.Content: Fast response, flawless OS with great apps and easy interface. Good sound and good battery life. highly recommended for all features.

Reviews.Title: Almost perfect
Reviews.Author: Too many toys
Reviews.Content: I've had my 32GB Nexus 7 for several months. I use it every day. I do email, surf the web, watch Netflix and other videos, listen to music read books. A full review would be redundant, so what is wrong with this device and why not give it 5 stars? First, no video out solution. Second the output volume is too low to consistently understand speech using the speakers or a headset. I am hearing impaired, but don't have this problem with any of my other portable devices. Third the backlighting adjusts frequently, seemingly for no reason. This appears to be a design problem that some have corrected with some non-trivial surgery. In general, the backlighting cannot be adjusted low enough. When trying to read or watch videos in the dark it is far too bright and for the power conscious they will not appreciate the wasted power. I've listed all of the things I don't like about the device knowing that there are many very particular folks who will lose their minds over these type problems. Considering all of these issues, I am still really pleased with my Nexus 7 and don't think there is a better 7" tablet out there (or 7.9" one). If you want perfect, I doubt you will find it, but you can certainly spend an extra $180 trying. Good luck.

Reviews.Title: Could Be Exceptional, If Not for Speaker Problems.
Reviews.Author: ZeeZee
Reviews.Content: I really like the Nexus 7.  It truly is revolutionary in the respect that it brings high-end features at an exceptional price.  Unfortunately, I've had nothing but problems with the speakers.  After three units, all developing the same problem (audio distortion), I'm tempted to return it for the Samsung Nexus 10.  I'm just not convinced that Asus has the quality control under wraps.  The only other defective computer product I've ever owned was an Asus motherboard, back in the days of problematic electrolytic capacitors in many of their products around 2000.  I've not purchased an Asus product since, and now my opinion is absolutely ruined after three defective units, each within two weeks.  Essentially, the speakers become fuzzy and distorted only with 50-60% volume level.  I don't believe that the level is the problem, but is rather certain frequencies that kill the drivers.This is not an isolated incident.  Search Google and you will see that this is a common problem.  Asus needs to step up and correct the problem, because this is just nonsense.  Maybe it is just a bad run of the 32 GB model with SIM card, but this problem was also widely reported when the original models were released as well.

Reviews.Title: Great Tablet
Reviews.Author: M_Dubs
Reviews.Content: This is a great mini tablet. I bought it for my teenagers and they love it. It is great for gaming, movies, music, and has super fast internet (unless you have poor Wi-Fi connection)

Reviews.Title: You don't need to spend more money!
Reviews.Author: Paul S. Brzozowski "Tennessee"
Reviews.Content: After doing mucho research, and after justifying that I need a tablet so I can get on the Internet in my home without leaving my recliner, I popped for the Nexus 7 32Gb.I could not be happier.I love:Auto upgrading,(Mine went to Android 4.2 a few days ago),  the screen size, the ability to purchase off the Amazon store as well as the Google store, the ease of the menus, e-mail, Internet, YouTube, and the ease of which it downloads apps on demand, battery life, the color is just fine and the print is great. You can also download apps to hook onto a USB drive without any trouble at all.  I just cannot see the huge money difference between this and the fruit product.I don't like:The auto on function of Facebook telling me all my notifications whether I want them or not, having a credit card number somewhere inside the unit for buying apps, and so far, although I know one is probably out there, no real good way to virus protect, or a firewall. AVG, where are you??I don't plan on using it outside my house, since I don't trust open Wi-Fi in places like Starbucks and the like.Otherwise, if you are looking for a tablet, I HIGHLY suggest you at least give these a ride and see what you think.Oh, by the way, Big Lots carries a nice, neat pouch unit with zippers that holds the unit and all the accessories like earbuds, stylus, etc, in another pocket without letting them touch the tablet itself, and it has zippers for everything. Cost? $6.00UPDATE:Found AVG for tablets, runs great, updates automatically.Main uses now: E-mail, FB, buying things, playing games, getting news and weather.  Still believe this is a fantastic tablet and will continue to use it.  BTW, battery life is great.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic and Versatile Tablet
Reviews.Author: MarkC
Reviews.Content: Bought this totally without any regrets. It's small enough to carry anywhere and can even be slipped into my big pockets on my cargo pants. The feel is absolutely buttery smooth and an IT friend even said the response is even better than the "other" thing.The OS updated 3 times since I switched it on and no more ISP bloatware and long delays before the OS gets updated.I use this as an everything-can-do to surf, read emails and ebooks. The quad-core makes surfing and installing apps a fast experience.Makes me wish I could also get the Nexus 4.

Reviews.Title: Nexus 7
Reviews.Author: Akaiken
Reviews.Content: I love it, I really wanted an economic tablet for reading and browsing and also not that big and this is it. I just added my account and all my settings from my galaxy nexus were there

Reviews.Title: Great product!
Reviews.Author: bigdaddybesbris
Reviews.Content: It's stock Jellybean 4.2.1 with Tegra 3 quad-core processor and a gig of ram, this thing's a beast, what do you expect! :)

Reviews.Title: very good
Reviews.Author: V. Nguyen
Reviews.Content: everything's perfect and very fast shipment. nice. see u next time again for the next order.nothing to complain about!

Reviews.Title: It was great until Google broke it
Reviews.Author: sleepingsickness
Reviews.Content: Read all the positive reviews if you want to see how it worked before Google decided to brick the 2012 Nexus 7s. When they upgraded the os in November of 2013 (from Jelly Bean to KitKat), the battery life flew out the window as soon as it updated. It literally loses 10% charge per 30 mins of screen-time when it's plugged in and charging, and 20% if it isn't charging (yes, in safe mode). Search for this device and "battery life" and you will see how widespread this problem is. The first week of December 2013 they released an emergency update to fix the fix - and guess what that did? Stopped the units from charging AT ALL. After jerking around with me for that month (being passed from bot to bot getting the exact same script each time), support's next communication with me, five days after my warranty had expired, said maybe it was time to buy another one since after all it's past warranty coverage. I loved this tablet for the (almost) year that it worked, but I would never give the companies involved my $ again. The company who sold it broke it, won't allow us to remove updates and go back to when it did work, and tech support was nonexistent.

Reviews.Title: No SIM Card, Good Customer Support
Reviews.Author: Bill Baehr "whipperin1"
Reviews.Content: 03/07: I got my Nexus 7 yesterday from Google and it did not come with the Sim card. There was an envelope for the card but it was empty and the card was not installed in the device either. I called Google Support and they instructed me to send the Nexus 7 back and get a replacement Nexus 7 in order for Google to send me a Sim card. Seems pretty wasteful on Google's end. Google also charges my credit card for the replacement device until Google receives my defective device. Couldn't they just mail me a Sim card?The Google Support call was good. I talked to an English speaking person that sounded like she was from the USA. I really dislike trying to have a support conversation with someone from Mexico or India or any other foreign land. I was not put on hold either which is amazing!I also had a problem with the Nexus 7 not connecting with my Wifi at first. It did eventually connect. Once connected the Nexus 7 performed very well. It looks well made. The voice search feature was fun and it made very few mistakes recognizing words.  I will add to the is review as time goes on and hopefully be able to end up giving the Nexus 7 four or five stars.03/08: I received a replacement Nexus 7 device today and guess what? No Sim card was included. Please see my video. I called Google Support and they did promised that I would receive an email from a Support Specialist within 24-48 hours about getting me a Sim card. Why can't Google just mail me a SIMS card?03/11/13 On Friday afternoon, I stopped by the Woodland, California, AT&T; store to see if they would give me a SIMS card to use in my Nexus 7. They had one but they wanted a $36 activation fee. I declined. When I called Google support on Friday, I was promised an email from Google Support Specialist within 24-48 hours to resolve this matter. It has been over 72 hours and I still have not received and email from Google Support.  I am looking forward to Google resolving this issue.03/12/13 Called Google Support today to find out what is up with the Sim card since I did not get the promised email from them. Google Support suggested that I go to a local AT&T; store for a Sim card and they said I was supposed to get an email to do that on March 10. I did not get the email. I explained that I already went to an AT&T; store and AT&T; wanted an activation fee of $36 for the card. Google said that the activation fee must be paid even if I got the card from Google. I told Google that the sales person at the AT&T; store said that I would not have to pay the activation fee if I got the Sim card from Google. Google Support said that all they can do is to send me another Nexus 7 with the Sim card. So, here we go again with another replacement process.03/12/13: Email exchange between Google Support and me: I called AT&T; and they will not set up a prepaid account without the Sim card that should have been provided with my Nexus 7. In order to set up a prepaid account I would need to have the Sim card that I paid for from Google. AT&T; suggested that I return the Nexus 7 for a refund because I am not being taken care of properly by Google in this matter and buy a tablet through AT&T.;I have been back and forth all day with Google Support. They finally figured out that I have to return the Nexus 7 for a refund and then wait up to 14 days after receipt for a credit to my account and then I can order another Nexus 7 with an AT&T; Sims card. What a mess! I love the product, so I will order a Nexus 7 without a Sims card instead. The Sims card feature is not work all this trouble for me.

Reviews.Title: Nexux 7 was a gift to replace a very slow Acer w/ Windows 7
Reviews.Author: J. Mershon
Reviews.Content: I don't know about others but, it seems that any notebook or netbook produced before 2011 is painfully slow. I've finally given up on Windows 7 and PC's because of this. It's just not right that a 2 year old PC is no longer able to keep up even after thoroughly cleaning the system of all spyware and other programs that slow consume memory making it frustrating to do simple tasks like browse and search the web, do email and download some music and videos on occasion.The Nexus 7 was the perfect solution for a device that can be used anywhere in the house or where there is access to WIFI. It is fast and because it is based on the Android operating system, there are countless applications for it. I must say that since I gave the Nexus to my wife, I'm using it more than I'm using my Ipad 2. In fact, I'm thinking about abandoning my Ipad altogether!

Reviews.Title: Satisfied
Reviews.Author: Bonita L. Roberts
Reviews.Content: Product met expectations. It is ludicrous to demand a certain number of words be typed into this space. Two more.

Reviews.Title: Rock Solid Android Tablet
Reviews.Author: K. Culp
Reviews.Content: I bought this at a local retailer. Highly recommend, I've owned a couple of Android tablets over the last year... this is by far the best one. The price of the 32GB recently dropped down to the same level as the 16GB, although for most people 16GB is probably enough. If in doubt (use games, plan to store lots of media) go for the 32GB model. I decided to do the 32GB because there is no expansion slot. In general, I try to stick with the "Nexus" on the phone as well because these units get updated from Google directly (at least for a 2 year period in the case of my phone). Of course, the first Android tablet I got only had about 6 months of updates (won't name the brand). My other tablet was 7 inch and this was my "sweet spot" as I can handle it easily etc. My adult kids have big iPads and the recent mini was somewhat attractive to me. Actually, I bought 2 of these (spouse) and my wife who is technically impoverished did fine with this as she has been using the Android phone. It really boils down to your ecosystem and we've leaned toward Android over the last 2-3 years. Not a retina display, but much higher resolution than the iPad mini, also this unit has a quad core processor and 1GB RAM. I can honestly say it is smooth as butter and we are happy with both Nexus 7 tablets. If you don't have any investment in the Apple line, definitely save some money and get the Nexus... I would say the 32GB Nexus is about $130 cheaper than a 32GB iPad mini and you will be happy with it. Do get yourself a gmail account (free and really a must as it integrates a lot of the things you do on the tablet - although I sync with a email/calendar server (Microsoft exchange) at work with no problem. Some new features of Android 4.2 (as of this writing) are Google Now (a Siri like program), and a "gestures" keyboard (a must as I hate tap typing on a keyboard - with this you "slide" your fingers to each letter and it is much faster). Screen brightness, battery life, Wifi ease of use etc. all are excellent. High quality materials - especially the glass - speed and ease of use easily match the Apple iOS tit for tat.

Reviews.Title: Still not sure
Reviews.Author: David W. Hunt "Skipper"
Reviews.Content: The best feature is the ability to dictate search requests to Google.  The voice recognition is very good, and very fast, and far better than SIRI.  But the results are stuck on a small screen.The Nexus 7 is very fast for Google searches using the installed Chrome browser.The NOW feature seems somewhat helpful, so far for me primarily for appointments, weather and traffic home.  Note that it is VERY hard to turn NOW on if you do not do so during the initial set up (check for on-line tutorials AND additional instructions if you want to, since the NOW option is in a tiny menu hidden under a keyboard if it is not activated).  I suggest you activate it during set up and turn it off later if you don't like it.I had higher hopes for using the Google Maps application on Nexus 7 on the road, but it is usable even without active WIFI and is does give turn-by-turn directions.  You must download the relevant map area, which is not an intuitive process, and the range of the map is limited.  But the real problems are:(i) You must select your route while connected through WIFI, since it cannot create a route without a data connection. You must plan your final destination before leaving WIFI coverage. DONT fully exit the application on the road, or you cannot get the route back - you can suspend it.(ii) As far as I can tell, it does not allow a route to more than one location.(iii) Dynamic rerouting works once you gave a route, but it is not very resposive - it did have the better route than a Garmin once, but you must wait quite a while.  Also, the maps stopped scrolling as I drove.(iv)  Be very careful, since it does NOT incorporate HOV restrictions and tried to route me on a restricted route.(v)  Also, forget about POIs on the road.  But with a WIFI connection, there are some good searching map-based searching tools.Speaking of the screen, for some reason Nexus 7 will not change to landscape mode except for videos and Skype.  It would be much better to have an unlimited ability to change from portrait to landscape to blow up text on the screen.The video playback of Ice Age (included for free) failed on several attempts.  It appears Nexus 7 does not have a very good WIFI antenna.  Playback quality was just ok with a great connection.The one speaker is almost useless - poor sound, low volume, wrong place for a movie.Skype was spotty, probably due to the weak antenna, although it did work very well once.  The pictures of me looked even worse than normal for Skype since the camera creates high contrast images, with lighted areas of my face washed out and shadows totally black.  The pictures of were very small due to the extreme wide-angle lens, which might be just as well given how bad they looked.  Also, you are forced to use landscape mode on Skype, so your camera is on the side - that is a real pain.You can access most Amazon contact using free apps.  Google refuses to allow Flash 9, so you cannot play Amazon movies or see animated radar maps, and who knows what else.  I find this totally unacceptable - an obvious attempt to force you to use the Google Play Store exclusively for movies.Be aware that the device requires you to sync up to a Gmail account for many features.  When you do, you have total Google integration either forced on you (Gmail/Gmail Calendar), or immediately available (Google+).  Good, if you want it.The Google Play Store demands to save a credit card to the Google Wallet on the Nexus 7 even to downlaod a freebie.  I do NOT trust the Nexus 7 to have my credit card number.  The device is not secure.  I am not sure I will ever buy from the Play Store as a result.The Nexus 7 can track your location using GPS, or by triangulating your position from known WIFI locations (a feature available on Google maps).  So, even though it is not able to use cell towers to figure your location like a phone, it may have a rough fix on you.  Decide if you want the Nexus 7 to collect this much information about you, which I am sure it will send to Google.  It can be turned off.The Nexus 7 is good about warning about many privacy issues when you load an app, but there are no details and it is not obvious how to selectively disable features of an app, assuming you can.  You have to wonder about the apps based on all the warnings.There are tow totally annoying ads from the Google Play Store on the home screen by default.  TO DELETE THEM, hold your finger on the ad, at which point an "X" will appear at the top of the screen - drag the ad to the X and it and all of its progeny are gone.  However, the top half of the home screen will remain blank und unusable.  If you add more than three shortcuts and one widget, you end up with a two page home screen, each of which is largely blank.There is no way to put the device into screen off mode to save the battery.  The default time is really short, and if you increase it through settings you basically have to live with more battery drain all of the time or turn it off entirely.The Nexus 7 takes some time to start up from off mode, no time from the screen off mode. The device is normally on all of the time, with just the sceen off.So, while I like it, I am concerned about privacy issues, quite disappointed about the Google Maps integration, annoyed by the refusal to allow landscape mode on demand and the insistance on Skype in landscape mode, annoyed by the Play Store ads and the loss of home screen when they are deleted, totally annoyed by the refusal to allow Flash 7, and disappointed by the poor antenna.  I may or may not keep it.

Reviews.Title: Form and Function!
Reviews.Author: MPBenR
Reviews.Content: Thus far, this tablet fits my bill. It's compact, powerful, attractively made, and very affordable. The google Play store doesn't receive the credit it deserves - there are so many good apps and having an android device already, I have wonderful access to reliable, dependable, quality applications. I was concerned over the 7" screen size, I'll admit, as I'm a student using the device first for reading and second for goofing off. Text books are very readable and easy to access with any number of powerful apps (Kindle, Play Books, Adobe Reader...) and novels are no harder to look than on any other LCD screen of comparable devices; that said, I can't say it reads like E-Ink but I dont mind for one!For this price and with a good battery life of 10-11 hours of reasonable use, it's perfect for a student on the go.The Tegra 3, 2gb internal memory, and 32gb of storage in addition to limitless cloud storage assuming you have access to WiFi which is very fast on this device, i must add, give it solid futureproofing.iPad? Not badNexus 7?New Kid on the Block; New Cool Kid on the block.

Reviews.Title: All you need
Reviews.Author: Raymond Marx "Space Trucker"
Reviews.Content: This one for all tab is all but, perfect. It will do for all but, large tasks and as more and more comes on the Play Store for it, it becomes even better and better. The only regret I have is, I didn't get the 10"! Now if I can only find a great base for it, that has a speaker and USB ports.

Reviews.Title: Battery DoA
Reviews.Author: Jason L.
Reviews.Content: I bought the Asus Nexus 7 32 GB Tablet as a Christmas gift for my father.  As soon as he tried turning it on by holding the power button for a few seconds the unit would not start.  I told him he probably needed to charge the Tablet for a few hours before being able to use it unplugged.  He charged the unit and when he he unplugged, the unit would just not power on.  It would only work when the power adapter was plugged in.I am RMAing the unit through ASUS and we'll see how the returned unit works.  Also, ASUS didn't provide anything for shipping fees and shipping materials.  I have to ship the unit when it returns BACK to my father as well.  What a big disappointment purchasing this product has been.  Will update.

Reviews.Title: Nexus 7 32g
Reviews.Author: kurt3228
Reviews.Content: My wife has been wanting a tablet for quite a while now. We were out with friends and they were talking about the IPad tablets they each had. I'm not an Ipad fan or Iphone for that matter. I had been looking at and comparing many tabs out there and ran across the Nexus lineup. I was really surprised at the specs and reviews (especially the ones that rated the Nexus above the Ipad mini). So after lunch with friends we went to the store that had a great price on the Nexus and I purchased the 32gig 7 for my wife's birthday, without here knowing of course! When we got home I put all of her information into it which loaded her apps, set up the wifi and it was ready to go.Pros: Very fast, clean look, great battery life, picture is amazing. I would definitely recommend this tablet, also since it is a Google/Asus product, updates are guaranteed unlike updates from other manufacturers running the android system. The Jellybean 4.1 system is smooth, fast and simple to use.Cons: There is no slot for a SD memory card, I don't know why although 32 gigs is should be enough. I probably should have dropped the extra $50 and got the one with network capabilities ( I found out later that you can purchase one from google that is unlocked and with AT&T; sim card for $299). No data plan or contract required! These weren't available at the time. I was able to purchase an app called tablet talk that lets the tablet function as a phone and you can text message with it using your cell phone.

Reviews.Title: Simply Awful
Reviews.Author: mg111
Reviews.Content: After making the decision over two years ago to go with Google, I recently decided to stay with Android for a tablet. After researching tablets, trying a few and considering value for the dollar I settled on the Nexus 7. HUGE mistake. First I have now had TWO of these tablets as the first one was defective out of the box. The first had some buffering issues and a defective headphone jack. I've now had the replacement for a couple of days and have found the headphone jack is also defective on this one. Multiple pairs of headphones tried, all of which work perfectly fine in other devices.The second major issue is the buffering. Watching a standard definition video,, high definition, doesn't matter. CONSTANTLY buffering. I'm fairly tech savvy and have been trouble shooting and adjusting settings. Checked the wireless signal which is rated excellent and has no issues with other devices and is only a problem with the nexus. Needless to say this one will be returned and I'll be getting a refund.If considering venturing into the android tablet market go with a quality brand such as Samsung. If you're not sold on Android go with an iPad. But whatever you do don't waste a dime on this junk by Asus

Reviews.Title: Worked well
Reviews.Author: eric hunter
Reviews.Content: Till I broke my screen. Otherwise worked great! Now I am trying to decide if I should replace the screen on it.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: D. M. Johnson
Reviews.Content: I previously had purchased a Nexus 7, so I decided to purchase another for my husband.  After plugging it up to charge the battery, it only blinked and would not charge.  I had to return it.

Reviews.Title: Slow shipping and suspect battery
Reviews.Author: S. Meiers "tekrytor"
Reviews.Content: The Nexus 7 is great but it seems this the battery is not holding a charge nearly as well as my wife's Nexus 7. I suspect these 2012 models batteries are aging. The shipping was also slow.

Reviews.Title: Ugh
Reviews.Author: JakeN440
Reviews.Content: Product works but the screen is glitchy and randomly presses spots that i am not, still wondering what to do with it

Reviews.Title: initally great then all down hill!!!!!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Initially my daughter loved this device ( she 13 and only had it for about 6 mo).  Had tons of great features BUT then cord would not stay plugged in to make connection to charge then just would not even hold a charge for a couple of hours.  Their customer service center sucks!  Could not be of any help said I could pay to send it in then would 90-150$ to fix it depending on problem. And take up to 2 weeks to turn around. Would not promise it would be fixed or replaced.  We had on similar problem with a kindle and there were no questions ask they shipped us a new one before the old one was ever returned and never had another problem.  Wish all apps we on kindle that are available on nexus it would totally not be question in my mind replace it.

Reviews.Title: Too many issues to use on a regular basis.
Reviews.Author: cb
Reviews.Content: When getting ready to purchase this tablet, everything about it looked really great. I like the physical design and size. The software used is really great. The fact that it is Google makes it even better, especially for syncing purposes. The problem = there appear to be a large number of defective models in existence. The primary issue with my particular device is instability when it comes to tracking my fingers. This has become so much of an issue that it basically renders the device useless. I bought the device to use as a quick reference with PDFs and other documents, and also to search the internet; the stability issue makes it very hard to actually scroll through documents and typing using the 'swype' function is virtually impossible; additionally, the screen frequently experiences 'phantom touches', causing inappropriate clicking and accidental mistakes. Forget any sort of gaming. Warranty services provided no help. Further research into the issue seems to indicate this is the result of a grounding issue that affected many of the Nexus 7 devices.Likes:- Physical design & size- Software design & syncing abilityDislikes:- Large # of defective models - results in touch input instability- Warranty services: To no avail, I went through a long period of communication with warranty services to try to fix the issue. They finally suggested that I mail the device to their warranty center, which I did and which resulted in $20 out of my own pocket. When I finally got the Nexus back, the only thing that came with it was a sheet of paper that summarized the complications I stated in my claim; there was no indication as to any solution they tried to implement, or if they attempted anything at all. The defect remained unresolved and communications from warranty services ended.- Processing: The device seems to run slow pretty often; however, this may be partly secondary to the grounding issue mentioned previously.

Reviews.Title: Junk! horrible warranty service, major reliability issues
Reviews.Author: Construction pro
Reviews.Content: I have had this tablet for exactly one year and I regret ever buying it.  I have been very gentle with it and never damaged it.  However, I have had to send it to Texas 3, yes that's right, 3 times for warranty service.  Twice I had to pay shipping to get it there - about $30 worth.  The first time they had to replace a defective gyroscope- it suddenly stopped rotating the screen.  The second time it would continually try to reboot itself.  A complete reset would not fix the problem.  They sent it back saying nothing was found defective, but they obviously reloaded the software because it worked when it came back- for about 1 month.  Then it broke down the third time.  It just suddenly tried to reboot itself and wouldn't quit with the little swirling colored circles on the screen.  It would not even let me complete a factory reset and it stopped even turning itself on.  Each time it breaks down, you have to send the thing to Texas for service.  They keep it for over a week after they receive it, before they ship it back to you.  When they do ship it back, it is Fedex, and if you are not home all day to sign for it you have to go to Fedex to pick it up- a 1/2hour drive each way for me.  The total turn around time each repair is about 3 weeks from the time you ship it out until it arrives back at your local Fedex.  In one year I have lost all my data 3 times, have been without a tablet for 9 weeks total, and now I am awaiting it being shipped back to me the final time.  The thing is, my warranty expired during the time they were working on it, so next time it dies on me- that's it, I'm out my time, money, and data.  Really horrible way to treat an Asus customer!  I have an Asus desktop and 2 first gen Nexus 7's and a second gen Nexus 7.  I doubt I will buy another Asus product.  Beware!  By comparison, I had a Bosch circular saw that died after a year and a half of light use.  It was out of warranty, however Bosch fixed it free of charge and I got it back in exactly 1 week from the day I dropped it at UPS to go to Atlanta.  Asus needs to take a lesson from Bosch on how to do customer service.  Asus, you have lost my loyalty.

Reviews.Title: Great Tablet
Reviews.Author: rb
Reviews.Content: I've had this unit for almost 5 months now, and really can't think of any complaints.  The size, video performance, ample storage capacity, and rapid processing all meet my needs quite well (I have not used it for processor-intensive games, so can't comment there).  Given the price drop since the 2013s arrived, it is a great value for the money that does everything it claims to do.  I would buy it again in a minute.

Reviews.Title: Asus Nexus 7 Tablet
Reviews.Author: hornet64
Reviews.Content: Love it !!! It is easy to use and as soon as I started it it updated to Kit-Kat 4.4.2.I would recommend it to anyone who would be interested in this type of tablet.

Reviews.Title: Simply Great!!
Reviews.Author: kokimac
Reviews.Content: It was a really good purchase, I have been using the Google Nexus without any problem at all!, :D :D

Reviews.Title: good product
Reviews.Author: Mariel Feder "mariel"
Reviews.Content: It is a good product, with very nice features.However, it is still far from the ipad touchscreen sensitivity. c

Reviews.Title: JUNK
Reviews.Author: James Decker
Reviews.Content: Got a 32 Gig Nexus 7 for Christmas.Twenty Three dead pixals. Glass lifted on one corner. Google willing to replace only if I shell out $300 for a new one, which they claim they will refund when they get the defective one. Called Asus: they said replacement would take 12-14 weeks.Will NEVER own another ASSus product! This one is going in the trash: Nice waste of $300

Reviews.Title: Died After 40 Days
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Died after Amazon's (Warehouse Deals) return period. Always a little hesitant to turn on, but I thought it was the model having always had IPads in the past. Now it does not turn on. It isn't the charger because I can use that to charge my android phone. Far too expensive for it to be a brick only weeks after being bought and only a handful of times being used. I have one unhappy kid on my hands, as well.

Reviews.Title: Device shipped broken out of the box
Reviews.Author: Delfino J Gutierrez Jr.
Reviews.Content: The screen was broken and it even looked used. The outer shell looked used with scratches. Returning for a refund.

Reviews.Title: why is there no small manual with the unit--I am new to these electronic units and really require a manual can you arrange for o
Reviews.Author: Hamish  Smith
Reviews.Content: why is there no Manual for this unit --could you please arrange for one to be sent to me Please

Reviews.Title: Disappointed!!
Reviews.Author: David Trent
Reviews.Content: Received my Nexus 7 today, this is my second N7 so when I found this one on Amazon at such a great price, I jumped on it. I opened the package and I have some type of foreign charger with it, not for US standard 120v outlets. I was able to use my old charger but I am very disappointed with this. Nexus 7 is a great tablet but 3 stars for the charger issue, this was a Christmas gift for my daughter.

Reviews.Title: The worst
Reviews.Author: Tracy Goodman
Reviews.Content: This product sucks worst thing ever! Would no chage! Never buy this product just a wast of your money ! Hate the product

Reviews.Title: Awesome Little Device
Reviews.Author: Viking
Reviews.Content: I bought it for my wife as an early Christmas present, thinking that perhaps I'd get to use it some too. She won't share though. *pout pout*

Reviews.Title: The best for deployed hubby!!!
Reviews.Author: CM
Reviews.Content: My husband uses this case on his tablet to protect it while deployed. He didn't want sand and other debris getting into his Nexus 7 or scratching the screen. This has worked way beyond his expectations. Couldn't be happier with this product, and shipping was right on time.

Reviews.Title: Would think before buying again!
Reviews.Author: Kristy Y.
Reviews.Content: Got it because it was supposed to work with Android.  Still haven't gotten it to work correctly and has been mainly useless.

Reviews.Title: Returned it for an iPad mini
Reviews.Author: A.Tyler
Reviews.Content: I had to return it.  The OS system is slow, clunky, and felt rushed.  I can not get used to how slow it is, and how often it freezes or force closes.  I am sitting there waiting for apps to open, getting forced closed on.  I thought this was the way to go based on reviews and the price being less than an Ipad mini.  It's not worth the frustration of how this runs, which isn't very smooth.  Save your money and get an iPad mini instead, the operating systems are night and day. The apps feel rushed and cheap, and there isn't that quality you would expect.  I know Apple has there problems too but there app store is just way above anything else.

Reviews.Title: DOA
Reviews.Author: Joseph Bergeron "Brobot"
Reviews.Content: I bought this tablet and it doesn't even work, I charged it, does't turn on, no google logo, no battery meter for when your android device is dead, nothing! I even called ASUS and they won't replace it, they told me to call amazon, and amazon will only give me a refund

Reviews.Title: Stopped work in less than a month
Reviews.Author: nicko post
Reviews.Content: The device stopped worked in less than a month. I guess i got a bad one, but before the mishap their was nothing much to complain about

Reviews.Title: great product
Reviews.Author: n. french
Reviews.Content: great tablet for the price, not disapointed at all!  Use it daily!  I got a super deal from Amazon and opted for the 32 mb for a steal of a deal!  I would recomend this to friends, it has worked flawlessly!  very pleased

Reviews.Title: Beware of ASUS
Reviews.Author: Richard G. Shieldhouse
Reviews.Content: I tried the new Nexus 7 out, and fell in love with it's speed, brilliant display, etc. However; two weeks after I got it, the machine refused to charge (a complaint I've received elsewhere).I called ASUS customer support and sent it back to them. (Unlike responsible mfrs., they require customers to pay for shipping.)  Several weeks later, I received no word from. Went to their website, plugged in the RMA number and learned they are awaiting customer response.  Customer response to what?  I called and got a rude agent on the phone who said they don't notify customers of problems.  She said she would escalate the RMA and I MAY OR MAY NOT RECEIVE WORD FROM THEM. I asked when I MAY hear from them and she said they can't tell me that.  2014? 2015?  They can't tell me. (By the time I receive this thing, the 50th iteration of the Nexus 7 will be out.) I've pretty much written this one off. I could have paid a bit more and gotten an iPad Mini, which I could have marched into the Apple Store had I had the same problem. I've learned the hard way that sometimes it's well worth the premium to pay for good customer service. (Like paying $100 more to fly to Europe on Lufthansa, Air France or KLM instead of nickel-and-diming US airline.)  With the Google name on the product, I assumed it would have quality support.
